newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Greek Cypriot couple seek asylum in Turkish north.
newsitem.headline: Greek Cypriot couple seek asylum in Turkish north.

text.p: A Greek Cypriot married couple have sought asylum in the northern, Turkish-occupied area of the divided island of Cyprus, Turkish Cypriot police said on Thursday.

"Iakovos Iakovou, 24, and Xenia Iakovou, also 24, a married couple, crossed and sought asylum," police spokeswoman Pervin Gurler told Reuters. She said the pair came to the self-declared Turkish Cypriot state on Wednesday.
Gurler did not say why the couple had sought asylum or how they had crossed the U.N.-patrolled Green Line cutting through the island.
Diplomatic and security sources said they passed through at Pergamos, a checkpoint manned by the Turkish military skirting a British military base in south eastern Cyprus.
"A decision about whether to hand them back to the south or any other steps to be taken will be made after an investigation is completed," Gurler said.
Initial reports that the couple had gone to the north in a last-ditch attempt to secure exit visas after failing to get one in the south could not be confirmed.
"They crossed over voluntarily in Pergamos and a member of Unficyp saw them last night," said a source in the U.N. force stationed on the island since 1964.
"They were in good shape. As we speak one of our guys is over there seeing what they want to do," the United Nations official told Reuters.
"If they want to return to the south we will help them. If they want to stay they will have to deal with the guys in the north."
Cyprus has been divided since Turkey invaded in 1974 in response to a Greek Cypriot coup in Nicosia that was backed by the military junta then ruling Greece.
Defections of Greek Cypriots to the northern parts of the island are extremely rare.
Only Ankara, which keeps some 30,000 troops in the north, recognises the Turkish Cypriot state.
